ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Institute Site has release prevention and emergency response policies and procedures in place in order to prevent and reduce the potential for releases from the Institute facility.  Written procedures are maintained and are followed by Institute personnel.  Release-reporting procedures are included in Institute's manufacturing process units which prescribe immediate and follow-up reporting to federal, state, and local authorities, including the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA), the U.S. Coast Guard, the West Virginia Division of Environmental Protection (WVDEP), the state and local emergency planning centers (EPCs), and the Metro 911 Center, as required by federal, state, and county protocol.  The plant maintains an emergency response team with appropriate training and equipment to respond to releases of toxic or flammable materials inside the plant.  The plant also has mutual-aid agreements with local fire departments for response to various emergencies including chemical releases.





FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



The Institute Plant is located eight miles west of Charleston, WV on the north bank of the Kanawha River.  The site has a total area of 460 acres, which is owned by Bayer CropScience.  Portions of the site are leased to Union Carbide (Dow), Praxair, and Reagent Chemical Company.



Bayer CropScience, an agricultural chemical based company, operates a multi-product, multi-process chemical plant.  The plant has three basic manufacturing units along with several other production facilities primarily responsible for producing raw materials used in the manufacture of agricultural chemicals.  The principal products produced at the Institute site are LARVIN brand thiodicarb, RHODIMET AT-88, and Carbosulfan.  Praxair, Catalyst Refiners, and Reagent Chemical operate their own facilities inside the site.



Bayer CropScience currently has one produ

ction process at this site that is covered by the RMP rule.  That RHODIMET AT-88 process supports the Adisseo Animal Nutrition business, which is operated for Adisseo by Bayer CropScience.  The RHODIMET AT-88 facility produces methionine hydroxy analog that is used in poultry feed supplies.  Ammonia is used as a raw material for this process.  



Processes no longer subject to the RMP rule are Methyl Isocyanate, Phosgene/Chlorine and Aldicarb as those processes has been permanently shut down.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Managing Process Safety at the Institute Site requires proactive identification, evaluation, and mitigation or prevention of chemical releases that could occur as a result of failures in processes, procedures, or equipment.  We maintain a process safety management program that requires a systematic approach to evaluating the whole process. Using this approach, the process design, process technology, operational and maintenance activities and procedures, non-routine activities and procedures, emergency preparedness plans and procedures, training programs, and other elements which impact the various covered RMP processes are all considered in the evaluation.  The various levels of protection  that have been incorporated into the design and operation of the unit process to prevent or mitigate the release of hazardous chemicals are evaluated periodically and  revised as needed to assure their effectiveness at each level.  Ultimately, the major objective of process safety management of hazardous chemicals is to prevent unwanted releases of hazardous chemicals which could expose our employees, the community and the environment to serious hazards.



The process subject to the RMP regulation is also subject to the OSHA process safety management (PSM) regulation.  OSHA's PSM regulation is intended to prevent potential releases inside the plant and the RMP program is meant to help control and pre

vent releases which may affect off-site human health or the environment.



Accidental releases from this process are prevented by studying the hazards of the processes and implementing procedures, installing control devices and systems, and providing training to control those hazards.  The process is periodically evaluated to assess the risk of the operations by current standards and to make improvements where necessary



In addition to skilled operators, the process has computerized control systems which monitor and record conditions within the process and adjusts accordingly.   The control systems are equipped with redundant safety systems which are designed to correct or shutdown the process if certain parameters are exceeded.   The process covered by RMP utilizes scrubbers and flares to neutralize emissions from the process and minimize potentially harmful releases to the atmosphere.  



Maintenance of equipment containing hazardous substances is also a key element in preventing accidental releases.  In addition, any changes made to the processes are carefully reviewed prior to implementation to ensure that safety and environmental risks are recognized and addressed.  Finally, while many steps have been taken to prevent accidental releases, in the event that an accidental release does occur, it is formally investigated to determine the root causes and to prescribe corrective actions to prevent the release from recurring in the future.





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Institute Site had no accidental release from an RMP-covered process that meets the RMP incident reporting criteria during the last five years. 



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Institute Plant maintains an on-site  emergency response team to handle fires, explosions, toxic vapor releases, medical, chemical spills, and natural disasters and rescue emergencies.  It also participates in local fire and industrial mutual aid systems.  The Institute Plant has a dedicated in-plant Emergency O

perations Center capable of modeling events using real-time meteorological data, trained incident commanders, and a trained and state-certified emergency squad on site at all times.  Additionally, a plant-wide notification system is in place in the event of an emergency.  The plant has an onsite dispensary and medical professional as well as full-coverage with Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs).



CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



There are many operating and mechanical changes that continuously occur to improve the safe operation of the Bayer CropScience facilities.  These occur as a result of the periodic risk-based process hazard assessment review process, as described above.



Since the last resubmission in 2011 Chloroform and Chlorine have been removed from the site as the result of process shutdowns.  Those shutdowns prompted the current resubmission.  The Rhodimet AT-88 process is planned to shut down permanently by September 1, 2012.  When that occurs, there will be no more RMP chemicals remaining at the Institute site.
